Ken,

   The cited example modification of the paper geometry problem was 
=
only to provide an instance in which the dimensionality of the 
substrate i=
nputs and outputs, as applied to the Hypercube inputs, as 
stated in the or=
iginal attempted general characterization, were of 
differing dimensionalit=
y.

   I believe the jist of your other contemporaneous conversations is 
t=
hat additional a priori knowledge maybe interjected via the 
Hypercube inpu=
ts, since:

(a) this additional information is associated with the substrat=
e 
input/output node, though not expressly represented in same, and

(b) th=
is additional information is segregated to either the "from" 
or "to" nodes=
 associated with the current substrate link under 
consideration.

   I am =
only attempting to clarify the seemly more general condition 
in which the =
additional "information" associated with a substrate 
input node is of diff=
erent content and/or dimensionality than the 
additional "information" asso=
ciated with a substrate output node 
(i.e. apples and oranges, not just ora=
nges and oranges). The 
specifics of the cited modified example is irreleva=
nt except in its 
attempt to illustrate this point.

Thanks,
   Andy Carl

ndy,

output

ode (yes/no); or you could have a multilayer 3D input field (where 
> each =
2D layer is a type of object) connecting to a 2D output field

h pixel answers the question, is there overlap here?).

xpress lateral connections, and you might 
not.

den layer or a 2D hidden layer.  You might

h case, the implications are different about how proximities

rated or expressed.  In some cases it can be explicit

e substrate; in some cases it is implicit.  For

y a single output node and a 2D sheet of

even need to take a target location 
> as input, since there is only one ta=
rget.  In that case you just

ming out of it.  In such

rovide a proximity

t within the

re also

hat 
> nearness even though it is not explicitly provided as input.
